bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, February 12, 1950

div1.p: Tate provides an autobiographical sketch and ponders why yellow fever seemed to spread to other parts of America from South America, but not from Africa to northern Africa or southern Europe.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, February 12, 1950
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3 California
February 12, 1950
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I am pleased and greatly interested in
your kind letter of January 16th. Was very sorry to learn
that Colonel Stark has been gone these many years. That
is one thing I don't like about the military services: A
good, deserving man can in some cases work out his life
for it and fail to get proper recognition.

Mine is only a layman's opinion, but I
feel sure that Stark had everything to carry him to high
rank, and for him to be in a position where he could be
shelved by someone opposing him, could occur only in the
military forces.

Of course, I'm sort of fanatical in re-
gard to the medical profession. I have always thought
that, in connection with the engineers, (but where would
they be without doctors) that medicine is the greatest
profession in the world.--No military rank can add to it.
But in the services that is all one has to look forward
to except personal satisfaction, and when a man is “tops”
he should get top rank. I am surely glad that you had no
inside enemies to stop your deserved advancement.

I remember when the detachment from Pinar
del Rio arrived at Columbia Barracks. Of course, as you
know, one of the first things an enlisted man asks upon
reporting at a new station is, “What kind of a C. O. have
you?” The report in this case was, “Fine!” One fellow, an
old soldier, remarked, “Hell, he looks more like a cavalry
officer than a doctor!” I well remember that you did have
a sort of dashing, military appearance.

Regarding your kind interest as to my
welfare in Berkeley: For about ten years previous to the
depression years my wife and I conducted a 12- acre Buff
Leghorn poultry ranch and hatchery at Orinda. We operated
three batteries of incubators and hatched and sold over
a thousand chicks a week.

Did very well until Hoof and Mouth disease
struck that locality and a dumb-head inspector included
baby chicks among live stock forbidden shipment. (A chick,
hatched after 20 days in an incubator and at once trans-
ferred to shipping container could not possibly transmit
this disease)

Three months of these restrictions put us in
financial difficulties, and just as we were recovering #
the great depression struck and that put us out of busi-
ness and we moved to Berkeley. I wrote fiction for the
pulps for awhile, but at that time there was no steady
living in it. Joined the Berkeley Unemployment Associ-
ation and became one of the directors until we dissolved
the corporation. Then I decided to advance thirty years
the old saying “that life begins at forty.”

At seventy years of age I wrote some letters
to various big manufacturing firms, applying for work; of
course omitting my age until the interview. This was be-
fore the war, but the manager of the H. J. Heinz Co. (57
Varities) laughed at my age and gave me a temporary job
in the stock room of their big plant.

I worked until the job was over. Before I could
take another place offered me by the Cal. Ink Co., Heinz
Co. called me back for a permanent job with them. Two years
later I was a key man, head of the receiving department.
Kept that until late 1946 when all men there over 65 had
to retire. As I was 75 I couldn't object! They even gave
me a retirement check, which was pretty good seeing that
I had begun work there when five years past the retirement
age!

Upon taking this job I spent my last dollar as
down payment on a house, (and was I lucky to get it!) A
$4,000. house that called for monthly payments for eight
years. As I received good pay I completed my payments in
four years. (Could have sold it during the war for $10,000.)

So now, with my pension and Social Security and
no rent to pay, I manage to get along very nicely in a
modest way. So do you blame me for feeling a little proud
of coming through so well after 70 years of age?

I've been interested in the Yellow Fever (Jungle)
experiments in Africa by Doctor Stokes and others. I wrote
I wrote to Doctor R. M. Taylor, of the Rockefeller Foun-
dation for some literature on the matter. He sent me a per-
sonal letter and enclosed a pamphlet on “The Epidemiology
of Yellow Fever,” being extracts from proceedings of the
Congress of Tropical Medicine, at Washington, 1948., and
said he would have the Publication Department send me other
literature regarding the matter.

What I can't understand is that mosquito--carried
Yellow Fever has reached from the South American jungles
to America many times during 200 years, and now we know
the vector and destroy it we have no more Yellow Fever in
America. They have this same mosquito (and several other
vectors in Africa) yet Yellow Fever has never been a great
scourge along Southern Europe or North African Cities.
Yet they claim that the virus strains isolated in Africa
and America are virtually identical. Well, I'm no scien-
tist, but it sounds funny. The Rockefeller Foundation
Publicity Department says they are sending me a list of
their publications from which I can select any I may wish
and they will send them to me, so perhaps I will learn more
about the African experiments.

I have not yet heard from the book store that
said they would try to get a copy of your book for me, so
(4)
I guess they will not succeed. When I am next in Oakland
I will try the stores there, for I certainly want to get
a copy.

Please do not think when you read these long,
disconnected letters of mine that I expect you to reply
to them in detail, or even think that you “owe me a let-
ter”--Not for anything would I wish that--I know you have
too many intimate things of your own to think of. Simply
think of me as a garrulous old man who likes to put his
thoughts graphically instead of vocally and hopes it won't
bore. You can't stop a talker, but a letter is like a radio,
you can cut it out when you wish, and with that thought
I'll ramble along.

I just received a copy of the Congressional Joint
Resolution, 396, establishing a Walter Reed Commemeration
Commission, sent me by Representative Bland, of Virginia.
I think it would be a wonderful tribute to Major Walter
Reed and all concerned. I will encolose you the copy, as
I have another sent me by Senator Jenner, of Indiania, who
presented it to the Senate. It must be having effect
even before it it is passed, for I heard a radio talk this
morning by a Doctor King, on the Yellow Fever experiments
in Cuba.
With very best wishes to you,
